meaning: A limit in which f(x) increases or decreases without bound as the value of x approaches an arbitrary number c.

Horizontal asymptotes are horizontal lines that the graph of the function approaches as x tends to +∞ or −∞. Vertical asymptotes are vertical lines near which the function grows without bound. A slant asymptote has a slope that is non-zero but finite, such that the graph of the function approaches it as x tends to +∞ or −∞.
A real-valued function whose graph does not have any breaks or holes.

word: Greatest Integer Function (Gauss Function, Floor Function)
meaning: The function that takes as input a real number x, and gives as output the greatest integer less than or equal to x, denoted floor(x) or [x].
A theorem regarding the limit of a function.
“Approach” or “Tend” are used to express “come near” in calculus. In mathematics, it is symbolically represented by a right arrow symbol.
A function is said to be continuous if it can be drawn without picking up the pencil. Otherwise, a function is said to be discontinuous.
A function which is either entirely nonincreasing or nondecreasing.
A theorem that will be dealing with all of the y-values between two known y-values.
There is no limit to its values.
How that quantity changes over time.
Process of finding the derivative, or rate of change, of a function.
A function is said to be differentiable if the derivative of the function exists at all points in its domain.
A linear function for which the range does not change no matter which member of the domain is used.

The product rule is a formula used to find the derivatives of products of two or more functions. The quotient rule is a method of finding the derivative of a function that is the ratio of two differentiable functions.
A formula for computing the derivative of the composition of two or more functions.
An explicit function is one which is given in terms of the independent variable. Implicit functions, on the other hand, are usually given in terms of both dependent and independent variables.
The process of finding the derivative of a dependent variable in an implicit function by differentiating each term separately.
A tool that allows relations to be converted to functions of several real variables.
Involve two (or more) variables that change at the same time, possibly at different rates.
